text.p: The vector space [mathjaxinline]C[0,1][/mathjaxinline] of continuous functions on the interval [mathjaxinline][0,1][/mathjaxinline] is given the inner product [mathjaxinline]\langle f,g\rangle = \int _0^1 f(t)g(t) \ dt.[/mathjaxinline] In this space, what is the distance between the functions [mathjaxinline]f(t) = t^2[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]g(t) = t[/mathjaxinline]?

font.p: Recall that the distance between [mathjaxinline]f[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]g[/mathjaxinline] is given by [mathjaxinline]\| f-g\|[/mathjaxinline], or, equivalently, [mathjaxinline]\sqrt {\langle f-g, f-g \rangle }[/mathjaxinline].
Hence the distance is [mathjaxinline]\sqrt {\frac{1}{30}}[/mathjaxinline]. These functions are pretty close to one another on the interval [mathjaxinline][0,1][/mathjaxinline]!
